thread.title: Origin flags lower earnings on weak prices
thread.title_full: Origin flags lower earnings on weak prices

title: Origin flags lower earnings on weak prices
text:
Thu, Aug 20, 2015, 12:23 PM AEST - Australia Markets close in 3 hrs 37 mins Origin flags lower earnings on weak prices AAP – 27 minutes ago Print 
Origin Energy shares have fallen seven per cent as the company flagged lower than expected earnings after falling oil prices contributed to a $658 million loss. 
The energy retailer and oil and gas producer expects intense competition in retail markets to continue and said its key Australia Pacific LNG (APLNG) project remains on track to commence production from the second quarter of the 2016 financial year. 
The net loss for the year to June 30 compares to a profit of $530 million in 2013/14, with a $705 million impairment charge from Origin's investment in Contact Energy and the weaker Australian dollar weighing on its latest result. 
Chairman Gordon Cairns said the 2015 and 2016 financial years were transitional years for Origin and market conditions remained challenging. 
"In our integrated gas business, we are mindful that the significant fall in oil price, if sustained at current levels, will result in lower growth in cash flow and earnings than previously expected," Mr Cairns said in a statement. 
Origin said its key priorities have been moderated to conserve cash flow and accelerate cost reduction, including limiting capital expenditure in the exploration and production business. 
Mr Cairns said the company would continue to focus on reducing operating and capital costs, realigning debt across the group and divesting assets. 
The company also said it had made strong progress on plans to reduce Australia Pacific LNG's total upstream cost structure by $1 billion per year as it implements company-wide cost savings of $200 million in the 2017 financial year. 
Origin said a reduction in revenue of around $300 million was primarily due to lower oil prices and the ongoing impact of intense competition in retail markets is expected to continue. 
At the end of the 2015 financial year the group had divested its 53.1 per cent interest in Contact Energy. 
Underlying profit fell four per cent to $682 million while revenue from continuing operations fell seven per cent to $11.55 billion. 
The company has $5.8 billion of committed and undrawn debt facilities. 
Origin shares were 76 cents, or 7.68 per cent, lower at $9.125 at 1153 AEST. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook AMP half-year profit up 33% AAP
